name: Starry Stonewort

Identifying Characteristics: Chains of single tube shaped cells form tentacle-like branches arranged in whorls

Tiny, cream-colored, star-shaped reproductive structures (bulbils) that occur at the base of branch clusters are diagnostic.  Even before they are evident to the naked eye the bulbils can be detected by feel, by gently squeezing the stems at the whorls; the tiny bulbils are distinctly "firm" relative to the soft gelatinous feel of the rest of the algae.
May have holdfast or be free floating; brown to dark green in color
Can form dense mats on the lake bottom
Biology: Colonies reproduce vegetatively through rhizoids and fragments, and sexually with star-shaped reproductive structures

Stoneworts anchor themselves to the bottom with colorless hair-like filaments called rhizoids. Rhizoids act as roots, absorbing nutrients and providing stability. Stoneworts also have the ability to absorb nutrients through all surfaces, not just the rhizoids.
Rhizoids and stem fragments overwinter in and on the sediment; growth begins when the water warms in the spring and continues through late fall

Native to Eurasia, and believed to have been introduced to this continent through ballast water contamination, starry stonewort was first recorded in North America in 1978, growing in the St. Lawrence River. It has since spread to many sites along the St. Lawrence, to portions of the Great Lakes region, (especially around Lake Ontario, parts of Michigan and New York) and more recently to New England (Vermont).
Habitat: Grows in freshwater to slightly brackish water, generally at depths from 1 to 7 meters
Prefers soft sediments; can tolerate low nutrient and light levels
Range: Worldwide, approximately 30 species in the US
